abstract.text: This proceeding explores some of the questions that connect the LHC and neutrino experiments: What is the origin of mass?
What is the meaning of flavor?
Is there direct evidence of new forces or particles?
The neutrino program investigating these questions is large and diverse.
The strategy here, to narrow the discussion, is to focus on relatively new ideas for experiments that may be less known within the LHC community.

body_text.text: Introduction
Despite the wide difference in energy scales, the LHC and neutrino experiments have a great deal of intellectual overlap.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This talk explored three high-level questions as examples:
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: • What is the origin of mass?
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: • What is the meaning of flavor?
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: • Is there direct evidence of new forces or particles?
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: These are questions that resonate with the LHC community.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In this proceeding, I explore information and ideas that the neutrino community adds to the debate.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This discussion of the neutrino program has two biases used to narrow the scope to a manageable scale for a 20 minute talk and 15 page proceeding.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: First, the approach is data-driven.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A separate talk at the symposium, by Stephen Parke, was given on neutrino theory, and the reader is referred to this for a more top-down approach to the questions.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Second, the emphasis is on highlighting recent experimental ideas which may be new to the LHC community.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This necessarily leaves out a large number of exciting, but better-known experiments, however some very good reviews of these are available in Refs.
body_text.section: Introduction
Introduction

body_text.text: The νSM
The discussions below assume a "neutrino Standard Model" (νSM).
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: This is a minimal increment to the Standard Model driven by the present > 5σ results.
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: This phenomenology has been developed with an agnostic approach to the underlying theory.
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: It simply describes the data.
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: At this point, as demonstrated by LEP, we know that there are only three active flavors, ν e , ν µ and ν τ , with masses less than M Z /2 [6].
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: We know that these are related to at least three mass states, ν 1 , ν 2 and ν 3 , although there is not a one-toone correspondence.
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: In fact, the data are consistent with very large mixings with the mass states [7]: Reaching this level of accuracy, with every element of this Pontocorvo-Maki-Nakagawa-Sakata (PMNS) matrix measured at some level, represents a highlight of the work of the last decade in neutrino physics.
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: The limits on neutrino mass from kinematic studies of tritium beta decay indicate that the neutrino mass states are less than ∼ 1 eV [8].
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: We know that at least two of the three mass states must have non-zero mass, because we have measured two distinct mass splittings in oscillation experiments to high accuracy in atmospheric [9] and solar neutrino experiments [10].
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: Three neutrino mass states can be mapped onto two distinct splittings, and, when combined with reactor [1] and accelerator neutrino experiments [2], yield ∆m 2 31 = (2.473 ± 0.069) × 10 −3 eV 2 and ∆m 2 21 = (7.50 ± 0.19) × 10 −5 eV 2 [7].
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: These additions to the Standard Model (SM)-that neutrinos mix as per U P M N S , and that at least two mass states are nonzero with mass less than 1 eV-are assumed throughout the discussion below.
body_text.section: The νSM

body_text.text: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?
With the discovery of the Higgs, we have made a major step forward in understanding how mass terms should appear in the SM Lagrangian.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: However, as highlighted at the conference, the underlying meaning of the fermion mass spectrum we observe is unclear.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Moreover, we have yet to find any indication for a mechanism which prevents the masses of all fermions from being at the Planck scale.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: So, obviously, something is seriously wrong.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: We need more clues.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: A place to look for more clues is the neutrino sector.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Other than the facts that at least two neutrino states must have non-zero mass and that the mass spectrum corresponding to the active flavors must be less than ∼1 eV, we know very little about neutrino masses.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Our limited knowledge raises a host of other questions: How far below the upper limits do the neutrino masses lie?
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Why would the coupling of the Higgs to the neutrinos be more than five orders of magnitude less than the couplings to the charged fermions?
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Can there be other mass-producing mechanisms at play that lead to this effect?
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: And will neutrinos have the same mass hierarchy as the quark sector, with the small splitting seen at the lowest masses and the large splitting associated with the highest mass?
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: These are all questions we can investigate in the next decade to shine more light on the continuing question of the origin of mass.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: At present, we know that the gap between the neutrino mass states of the νSM and the electron mass is five orders of magnitude, This is as large as the span of masses of the charged fermions, from electron to top quark.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: However, this is just a limit in the neutrino sector, and the lightest mass state might be as low as (∆m 2 31 ) ∼ 50 meV, leading to a "desert" between the fermions of 10 7 eV.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: As we think about the problem of mass, we must consider what produces such a gap.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: There are two opposing approaches.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: One introduces new physics into the νSM, such as the See-saw Model [11] to motivate the gap.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The other argues that the masses are just an accident of nature, like the orbits of the planets, and, as in the case of orbits of planets, gaps happen.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: However, to push the analogy further, the study of the Mars-Jupiter gap has given interesting insights into the formation of the solar system and potential exo-solar-systems; similarly, even if the specific values of our fermion mass spectrum turn out to be accidents of nature, the origin of this "gap-feature" may lead to interesting insights in particle physics.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The first question, then, is: How big is the gap?
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The most precise method of attack comes from the study of the kinematics of tritium β decay [8].
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Neutrino mass will lead to a lower endpoint of the β-decay spectrum.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: These experiments measure m νe , which is
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: where the sum, i = 1..3, is over the three mass states.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The allowed values of m νe in nature depend upon
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: 1) the absolute offset of the neutrino mass states, which is the equivalent of the mass of the lowest state, and
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: 2) the mass hierarchy.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: To illustrate the point, consider Fig. 1, which is a cartoon of possible values of m νe as a function of absolute offset, where left and right apply to the two hierarchies, shown in inset.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: If the absolute offset is large with respect to the mass splittings, then there is little difference between the potential m νe values for the two hierarchies-this is called the "degenerate range."
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: However, for smaller values of offset, there is a substantial difference in the range of possible values which must be probed.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: To see this, consider the inset diagrams, where each bar represents a mass state and the colors indicate the flavor mixings.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The mass state ν 3 is defined to have the smallest electron flavor content.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The normal hierarchy (left) places ν 3 at the top of the mass spectrum, thus the highest mass state contributes a small weight in Eq.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?
What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: On the other hand, the inverted hierarchy places ν 3 at the bottom, resulting in large electron-flavor content in two high mass states.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This inverted arrangement allows an experiment with sensitivity below m νe ∼ 0.05 eV to cover the entire range of potential values.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: KATRIN, which will run in 2015, will be the first experiment to weigh in, and will have a sensitivity of ∼ 0.2 eV at 90% CL [12].
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This will cover the degenerate range of potential solutions.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: KATRIN is a classic electromagnetic spectrometer.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: To reach high resolution at the β-decay endpoint, the central region of the spectrometer must be 10 m in diameter, which is enormous and is likely to make the KATRIN experiment the last of its kind.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: To move to the next order of magnitude in sensitivity a new technology is required, and an interesting possibility has been put forward by the Project 8 collaboration [13].
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This technique traps the β s from tritium decay in a magnetic bottle.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: As the electrons traverse the bottle, they will radiate in the RF, at the fW level.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: In principle, the radiation can be observed with MHz antennae now under development as listening devices for cell phones.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The combination of time-of-flight and the frequency of the radiation allows the electrons with energies at the very endpoint of the decay to be isolated and counted.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This has the potential to push the sensitivity to m νe down to ∼ 0.02 eV, covering the entire range of potential values in the case of the inverted hierarchy.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: A related question to the absolute mass offset is whether neutrinos acquire mass in the same way as the other fermions.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Because neutrinos are neutral with respect to the electromagnetic and strong forces, they can, potentially, be their own antiparticle-where neutrino and antineutrino are distinguished by the spin state.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This allows introduction of an additional "Majorana" mass term, beyond the Higgs mechanism, into the Lagrangian.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Through the See-saw model, this mass term can be connected to physics at higher energy scales, leading to an explanation of the large mass gap we observe.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The most precise way to test for the Majorana nature of neutrinos is through neutrinoless double beta decay (0νββ).
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This is the neutrinoless analogue to the observed process of double beta decay to ββν eνe , which has been observed to occur in the handful of elements where single beta decay is energetically forbidden.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: In the case of 0νββ, the two antineutrinos annihilate-allowed by their Majorana nature.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: While it might be surprising to think that total lepton number can be violated in this way, in fact nothing in the SM prevents this.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: So under the argument that, "if is it not forbidden, it is compelled," 0νββ is natural.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The signal for 0νββ is the production of two monoenergetic electrons at the endpoint of the β spectrum.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Thus these experiments have a great advantage in knowing exactly where to look for a new physics signal.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The expected rate is related to a flavorweighted neutrino mass:
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The allowed values of m ββ as a function of absolute mass offset are shown in Fig. 2 for the inverted and normal mass hierarchies, overlaid.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The basic form is similar to that of m νe from the direct mass searches, with a degenerate region for large absolute offsets and larger average mass expected for inverted rather than normal hierarchy.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: But the differences in flavor-weighting (compare Eqs. 2 and 3) lead to a spread of potential allowed values in the 0νββ case arising because the elements of U can have arbitrary phases.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: As a result, the allowed regions are wide bands on Fig. 2.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: An accurate measurement of m νe can allow us to hone in on these CP -violating phases if 0νββ is observed, providing valuable input to Leptogenesis models [14].
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The progress in the search for 0νββ is indicated by the yellow shaded region, which are the limits from EXO and KamLAND-Zen [3].
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The excluded region becomes pale in the lower regions, indicating the theory error from the calculation of the nuclear matrix element of Xenon.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The theory error for all of the potential 0νββ elements is large.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This has led to a set of next generation 0νββ experiments that employ a range of different elements, so that cross comparison of signals and limits can allow a precise interpretation of the results with less sensitivity to the underlying nuclear theory.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The elements include Neodymium (SNO+), Tellurium (CUORE, potentially SNO+), Germanium (GERDA and Majorana) and Xenon (NEXT, as well as continuations of EXO and KamLAND-Zen) [3].
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: As with the direct mass measurements, the ambition of the next generation is to entirely cover the potential values of m ββ for the inverted mass hierarchy.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Each of the above experiments is pressing for improvements to reach this level, and it is unclear, which, if any, will succeed.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: However, an interesting new step is being pursued by SNO+, to switch from Nd to Te, which may make this experiment the first to pass below the inverted hierarchy in sensitive.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This step can be taken because of a very nice synergy among neutrino experiments.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: A set of recent reactor-based experiments has solved the problem of doping scintillator oil with a high fraction (a few percent) of metal isotopes [15]-research pursued to improve the neutron capture cross section in those experiments.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This same technology appears to allow SNO+ to dope with 3% Te.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Since the natural abundance of the double beta decaying isotope of Te is 34%, this results in sensitivity across the full range of potential mass values for SNO+, assuming they can achieve the necessary resolution at the endpoint [16].
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: From the above discussion, it is clear that the hierarchy is playing a crucial role in accessing the physics.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Beyond this, the hierarchy itself is an interesting question, if one is seeking to make a model of fermion masses.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Thus, it would be best if the question of the hierarchy could be addressed separately from the quantitative mass measurements.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Luckily, this can be done in certain neutrino oscillation experiments.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: To understand the sensitivity of oscillations to the hierarchy, consider the three neutrino mass states propagating through the earth.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Because the earth is filled with electrons, the neutrinos feel a weak potential.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The effect of this potential on the propagation will be different for each mass state, because of the varying electronflavor content, leading to a change in the oscillation probability.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This "matter effect" is enhanced with energy and distance.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The sign of the matter effect is opposite for neutrinos and antineutrinos, and thus can be regarded as faux-CP -violation.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: But unlike true CP violation, the effect will appear in both appearance and disappearance oscillation experiments.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: From the above description, one can see that an ideal setting to search for matter effects, and thus determine the mass hierarchy, is long baseline oscillations.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: While the traditional approach has been to look to accelerator-based sources, if what one wants is extremely long baseline, with a high-rate of events in the 1 to 20 GeV range, then nothing beats a cross-earth atmospheric neutrino experiment.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: To this end, the IceCube Experiment is upgrading their Deep Core central region with additional strings of PMTs in order to explore this physics.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: This upgrade, called PINGU, can be completed on a relatively short timescale, and will have 3 to 5σ capability within a few years of running [17].
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: As a result, one can imagine the mass hierarchy question-normal or invertedbeing answered on the same timescale as the direct and 0νββ mass measurements.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: The combination of the three approaches to questions of mass is powerful.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: In the cases where both the direct and 0νββ experiments see signals, very valuable information can be added to the models for new physics at high mass scales, including Leptogenesis.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: With or without a signal observed in direct and 0νββ experiments, the result can constrain cosmology.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: It should be noted that cosmology gets a good fit assuming no neutrinos [18], and mechanisms have been put forward that reduce or eliminate the cosmic neutrino background [4], and so constraints from earth-based experiments are quite important.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: Lastly, there is the potential for experimental discrepancies that force us to entirely rethink our nascent understanding of neutrino mass.
body_text.section: What Can Neutrinos Say About the Origin of Mass?

body_text.text: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?
If one is looking for patterns in the SM, then the neutrino flavor mixings expressed by Eq.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: 1 are as strange as the neutrino masses.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Completely opposite to the quark sector, all of the off-diagonal entries in the mixing matrix are large.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Even the smallest entry, |U e3 | is an order of magnitude larger than its quark-sector equivalent.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: As with the case of the masses, it may be that this is just a random occurrence in nature-this model is called "Anarchy" in the neutrino community.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: But we are, at this point, far from the level of precision where it is time to just give up on searching for a pattern.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Indeed, Figure 3.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Measurements from the reactor experiments at various baselines, overlaid with a fit to ∆m 2 [23].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Improved measurements of θ 13 at multiple baselines will allow tests of deviations from the oscillation expectation due to non-standard interactions.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: neutrino physics is, now, at the level of precision of the quark sector in 1995 [19]: So a whole world of precision flavor measurement is only now opening up to the neutrino community.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The ultimate goal will be to develop unitarity tests that are as precise as those in the quark sector.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: However, this will require precision measurement in muon-totau and electron-to-tau appearance experiments.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Because of the tau mass suppression in charged current interactions, this requires high energy neutrino beams.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Since the oscillation length of these studies is fixed in the νSM by ∆m 2 21 and ∆m 2 31 , high energy inevitably means ultra-long baselines, which require ultra-high intensity.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Thus the only practical solution is a > 20 GeV neutrino factory, which will not be realized until far in the future.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Nevertheless, improving the precision measurements we can do today can potentially produce indications of new physics.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The neutrino community is very interested in models with non-standard interactions that produce instantaneous transmutation of neutrino flavor at production and interaction, as well as modify the oscillation probability.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Cross comparing results of matrix element measurements from different experiments may provide sensitivity to such effects.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: But before looking for something completely different than in the quark sector, one can also look closely at the νSM to ask if it is complete.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: We know that the quark mixing matrix has an arbitrary phase which leads to CP -violation.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: It is important to ask if such a phase is appearing in the lepton sector also.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: It would be quite striking if it did not, since this would speak against the dictum of "that which is not forbidden is compelled."
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: It would also be striking if the value were large, the opposite to the quark sector, as that would make the apparent dichotomy between the quarks and leptons even more sharp.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Thus, even if unitarity tests are far away, there are a great deal of important checks we can pursue in neutrino flavor physics in the near future.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: As an example of a precision BνSM search that we can do within the next decade, consider θ 13 .
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Since the PMNS matrix simply produces a rotation between flavor and mass states, the flavor mixing is most commonly parametrized as through three Euler angles, θ 12 , θ 23 and θ 13 .
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The relationship between the matrix elements and the angles is complicated except for one entry, U e3 , which depends purely on sin(θ 13 ).
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: This turns out to be the smallest mixing angle, and was only recently observed to be non-zero [7].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: This was an exciting result both for theories describing the PMNS matrix and also because non-zero θ 13 is crucial for the potential to observe CP -violation.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Neutrino physicists consider 2011-12 "The Year of θ 13 " for the neutrino sector, in the same way it was "The Year of the Higgs" for the LHC.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: And, now, like the Higgs, the next thing to do is explore this new measurement for hints of the unexpected.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: What has been reported by the Double Chooz [20], Daya Bay [21] and RENO [22] reactor experiments, was a deficit in anti-electron neutrinos at L/E ∼ 1/∆m 2 tam .
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: One sees immediately that the νSM makes very specific predictions as a function of L/E.

body_text.text: These are modified in the presence of non-standard interactions.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: And so an important next step is to test for this L/E dependence.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: We can already begin to test the L dependence of the θ 13 measurements, because the three reactor experiments are at different baselines [23].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Fig. 3 shows the data associated with the various baselines.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Daya Bay has a particularly complicated reactor-core to detector arrangement, and that is why they report results from many baselines.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The dot-dashed line shows the expectation from the νSM, allowing sin 2 2θ 13 to float and fixing ∆m 2 atm to the measurement from MINOS [24].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The solid blue line allows both sin 2 2θ 13 and ∆m 2 atm to float.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The result is a rather high value for ∆m 2 atm , but allowable within errors.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: However, there is clearly room for models beyond the νSM, introduced as sub-leading additions, to fit the data.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Understanding θ 13 is also key to the search for CP violation in the neutrino sector.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: CP violation will modify the oscillation probability of appearance experiments.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: For muon-to-electron appearance, which is a channel we can test in the near future, the oscillation probability is given by:  Figure 4.

body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: For the large values of θ 13 which have been observed, measurement of a nonzero CP -violating phase in the PMNS matrix (eq. 1) ensures non-vanishing baryon asymmetry [14].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The theoretical problem is how to quantify the effect so as to understand whether this is the sole source of baryon asymmetry.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Thus, CP violation is a place where experiment is pushing theory as hard as theory often pushes experiment.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Two outcomes are particularly interesting: if experimentalists provide a measurement of CP in the neutrino sector that is large, a major contribution to the baryon asymmetry is necessary [14]; and if the CP violation parameter is limited to less than 5 • , theorists must begin seriously considering how to explain zero CP violation in the lepton sector, when it is observed in the quark sector.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: CP violation necessarily requires an appearance experiment, and the most feasible channel is muon to electron flavor oscillations.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The classic, or "conventional," approach to studying CP violation is to exploit the change of sign in the oscillation probability by running with neutrinos versus antineutrinos (see Eq. 6).
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: However, an alternative method is to run strictly in either neutrino or antineutrino mode, and instead trace out the oscillation wave, which is modified by a nonzero value of δ.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Because non-standard interactions may also be occurring in the neutrino sector, measurements using both approaches is warranted.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: In either case, a precise measurement of CP violation is best done at low energies and relatively short baselines, where matter effects do not add ambiguity to the result.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The newest and most powerful proposal for a conventional CP violation experiment using neutrino and antineutrino muon-to-electron flavor oscillations is to be built in Sweden.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: This experiment [28] would make use of the European Spallation Source (ESS), now under construction at Lund, to produce a conventional decay-in-flight, wide-band neutrino beam peaking at about 200 to 300 MeV.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Operation of the ESS linac proton beam will start at reduced power in 2019, increasing to the full design power of 5 MW in 2022.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: To produce the neutrino beam, the 2.5 GeV linear accelerator would be upgraded by another 5 MW, allowing ∼10 23 protons per year for neutrino production, concurrent with the neutron spallation running.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: A large water tank Cherenkov detector can be located underground in a mine at a depth of ∼3000 mwe at two potential locations: Zinkgruvan, which is 365 km from Lund, and Garpenberg, which is 540 km from Lund.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: These locations offer very similar rock and depths to the Pyhäsalmi mine in Finland that is under consideration for a CERN long baseline program [26].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Data would be taken with 2 years of neutrino running and 8 years of antineutrino running.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The design of the water Cherenkov detector is that of MEMPHYS [27], which is 440 kt of water.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The resulting capability compared to other conventional beam experiments is shown in Fig. 4, which shows the fraction of δ-space covered at 1σ for a given precision in δ.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The ESS experiment (purple) substantially outperforms the other proposed conventional designs (LBNE (green) [29] and T2HK (blue) [30]) due to several factors.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: First, the low energy of the ESS beam highly suppresses neutral current events in the detector that produce π 0 's, the principle and pernicious background to ν µ → ν e measurements.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: At this energy, the electron-like charged current quasielastic events are straightforwardly separated from the muon-like events in an ultra-large Cherenkov detector, as has been well-established by past experiments [38,32].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Second, while most low energy conventional beams are produced via targeting off axis, which yields a narrow band beam which limits reach in δ, the low energy of the ESS beam provides low proton energy and produces a wide-band beam.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Third, if the 540 km ESS baseline is used, then the resulting energy distributuion of the flux allows forthe study of the second oscillation maximum.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The CP violating asymmetry is significantly larger at the second maximum than at the first maximum, enhanced by the large value of θ 13 .
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: In contrast, the LBNE and T2HK designs, which were set before θ 13 was measured, were chosen to be most sensitive to the first oscillation maximum.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The alternative approach to measuring δ is to measure the change induced in the oscillation wave as a function of L/E.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The first proposal to pursue this method has been developed by the DAEδALUS collaboration [35].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: This experiment uses cyclotrons at three sites to produce identical neutrino fluxes from the decay-at-rest of pions and muons.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Events from the near cyclotron site allows constraint of the initial flux.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The middle and far sites then allow the shape of the oscillation wave to be accurately measured.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The useful flux from decay at rest beams range from 20 to 50 MeV, and thus this is a very short baseline experiment, with the sites located at < 1.5, 8 and 20 km.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Aν µ →ν e signal can be detected in a large detector with free proton targets (water or scintillation) via inverse β decay (IBD), ν e + p → e + n).
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: In the case of a water detector, in order to observe the neutron capture, Gd-doping, as is presently done in the EGADS experiment [33] is required.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Thus, this experiment could use the same detector as is planned for ESS.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Other detectors under consideration are HyperK (water) [30] and LENA (scintillator) [34].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Fig. 4, red, shows the DAEδALUS capability for a 10 year run [35].
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: While this sensitivity was calculated for running DAEδALUS with the Hyper-K design, the result when paired with ESS will be very similar.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: This capability is similar to that of the ESS proposal, and both approach the measurement of δ in the quark sector (gray band).
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: The combination can take the measurement of δ beyond a simple measurement, to a strong test of the potential presence of non-standard interactions.
body_text.section: What Can We Learn From Neutrino Flavor Studies?

body_text.text: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?
This is the question that unites physicists across many subfields.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: In the discussion, we have already highlighted several neutrino experiments where new, non-standard forces may be observed.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: So here, we consider the potential to directly produce and observe new particles.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Direct production of new particles has been widely regarded as the preserve of the highest energy scale experiments.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: However, new developments in dark matter [36,37] and sterile neutrino studies have recently sparked interest at high-intensity, low energy experiments.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: As an example, consider light (0.1 to 10 eV) sterile neutrinos.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Several anomalies have motivated the search for light sterile neutrinos with mass ∼1 eV.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The results arise from short baseline accelerator, reactor and source experiments [38,39,40,41], and include both neutrinos and anti-neutrino scattering, electron and muon flavors, and more than two orders of magnitude in energy range.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Models which introduce one, two or three sterile neutrinos, referred to as "3+1", "3+2", or "3+3," respectively, have been introduced to explain the data [42].
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Global fits have identified ranges in this extended parameter space where the anomalies can be reconciled in the 3+2 and 3+3 cases [43].
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Until now, all of these measurements have been made at specific L values and with rather limited ranges in E. An important goal of the next generation of these searches must be "oscillimetry," where the oscillation curve is traced in L/E space in a single experiment.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: This is the only way to clearly establish that these anomalies arise from oscillations rather than from some other non-standard, or indeed some unexpected standard, effect.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Sufficient sensitivity to make a definitive > 5σ statement is required.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The experiments that can make decisive measurements are based on pion/muon or isotope decay-at-rest (DAR) sources.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The DAEδALUS experiment described above could be used to generate a pion DAR beam for such a measurement.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: However, a proposal which uses the DAEδALUS injector cyclotron, called IsoDAR, can come on line much more quickly and produce a definitive result.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: This design uses protons from the injector cyclotron to produce neutrons, which then capture on 7 Li to generate an isotope DAR source.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Positioned next to a kiloton-scale scintillator detector such as KamLAND, one can search for sterile neutrinos by observing a deficit of antineutrinos as a function of the distance L and antineutrino energy E across the detector [44].
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Specifically, the proposed IsoDAR target will be be placed 16 m from the center of the KamLAND detector.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The antineutrinos propagate a distance of 9.5 m, through a combination of rock, outer muon veto, and buffer liquid, to the active scintillator volume defined by a 6.5 m radius nylon balloon.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The antineutrinos are then detected via the IBD interaction.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The excellent energy and position resolution of KamLAND leads to a well-reconstructed L/E for the event.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Example data sets for favored 3+1 and 3+2 sterile neutrino parameters are shown in Fig. 5.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The production of sterile neutrinos connects directly back to the LHC physics.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The previous discussion has considered heavy neutrinos in the ∼ eV range.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: However, much heavier neutrinos, in the 100s of GeV range, can arise from certain see-saw models and loop models [11].
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Fig. 6, from Ref.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: [4], presents possible allowed masses and Yukawa couplings of sterile neutrinos within seesaw models.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The right panel summarizes the role that these sterile neutrinos may play in solving Standard Model problems and Beyond Standard Model anomalies.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: The final column shows the preferred type of experiment to address the sterile neutrino, underlying the very strong connection between the experiments discussed in this paper and the LHC.
body_text.section: Is There Direct Evidence of New Forces or Particles?

body_text.text: Conclusion
This review has highlighted the strong intellectual ties between LHC and neutrino experiments.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: We have explored the intellectual overlap through three example questions: What is the origin of mass?
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: What is the meaning of flavor?
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: Is there direct evidence of new forces or particles?
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: However, these are only a few of the questions which bridge the two communities.
body_text.section: Conclusion

body_text.text: The richness of particle physics as a field can be seen by the way these two very different approaches to experiments push the community toward new ideas and questions.
body_text.section: Conclusion
